clinical_study.brief_title: Lactobacillus Reuteri DSM 17938 in Preventing Nosocomial Diarrhea in Children
clinical_study.official_title: Effectiveness of Lactobacillus Reuteri DSM 17938 in Preventing Nosocomial Diarrhea in Children: a Randomized, Double-blind Placebo Controlled Trial

brief_summary.textblock:
AIM: To determine the efficacy of Lactobacillus reuteri DSM 17938 at a dose of 10(9) CFU for the prevention of nosocomial diarrhea.
TRIAL DESIGN: Double-blind, placebo controlled RCT. INTERVENTION: L reuteri DSM 17938 in a daily dose of 10(9) CFU. PRIMARY OUTCOME: Nosocomial diarrhoea (3 or more loose or watery stools in a 24 h that will occur more than 72 h after admission).

detailed_description.textblock: Nosocomial diarrhea is a common problem in hospitalized children. Previously, it has been documented that the administration of L reuteri DSM 17938 at a dose of 10(8) colony forming units (CFU) compared with placebo had no effect on the overall incidence of nosocomial diarrhea (Wanke & Szajewska, J Pediatr 2012). Whether higher doses of L reuteri DSM 17938 have such effects needs to be substantiated in further randomized trials.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.measure: Incidence of nosocomial diarrhea (defined as the passage of 3 or more loose or watery stools in a 24-hour period that will occur more than 72 hours after admission)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Any time starting 72 h after admission

secondary_outcome.measure: Incidence of diarrhea- passage of 3 or more loose or watery stools in a 24-h period
secondary_outcome.time_frame: from the time of admission to the time of discharge of the hospital-expected average 3-5 days

secondary_outcome.measure: Duration of diarrhea (ie, time till the last loose or watery stool from the onset of diarrhea)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: during hospitalisation (expected average 3-5 days) and 72 h after discharge

secondary_outcome.measure: Need and the length of intravenous rehydration due to diarrhea
Prolongation of the hospitalization due to nosocomial diarrhea
Incidence of rotavirus diarrhea (ie, detection of rotavirus or antigen in the stools)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 72 hours after admission to the hospital to 72 hours after discharge
secondary_outcome.description: Positive test for rotavirus or antigen in the stool sample

secondary_outcome.measure: Incidence of chronic diarrhea- lasting more than 14 days
secondary_outcome.time_frame: untill 14 days after onset of diarrhea
During hospitalisation (expected average 3-5 days) plus 72 h after discharge

arm_group.description: Lactobacillus reuteri DSM 17938,10(9)CFU/daily (for the duration of hospitalization) ARM I: Rotavirus vaccinated patients ARM II: Non-rotavirus vaccinated patients
Placebo consists of an identical formulation in all respects except that the live probiotic bacteria were excluded for the duration of hospitalization

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Children aged 1-48 mo admitted to the hospital for reasons other than diarrhea
- Signed informed consent.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Acute gastroenteritis within 3 days before admission
- Symptoms other than diarrhea suggesting gastroenteritis
- Use of probiotics within 7 days before admission
- Immunodeficiency disorders
- Breastfeeding >50%
- Underlying gastrointestinal tract disorder
- Malnutrition (weight/high <3pc)
